text: Metaculus is a reputation-based, massive online prediction solicitation and aggregation engine.Predicting the Future (of Life), in Future of Life Institute published January 24, 2016 retrieved March 16, 2019 One of the focuses of Metaculus is predicting the timing, nature and impact of scientific and technological advances and breakthroughs.The power of prediction markets, in Nature, published December 17th, 2018 retrieved March 16, 2019This Site Keeps Track of Elon Musk’s Predictions About The Future, in Futurism published March 10, 2016 retrieved March 16, 2019 ==Reward system== Three types of predictions can be made: probability predictions to binary questions that resolve as either 'yes' or 'no', numerical-range predictions, and date-range predictions.The power of prediction markets, in Nature, published December 17th, 2018 retrieved March 16, 2019 Users can contribute to the community prediction for any given question, leave comments and discuss prediction strategies with other users.Metaculus: a prediction website with an eye on science and technology, in YaleNews published November 2, 2016 retrieved March 16, 2019 Users can suggest new questions which, after moderation, will be opened to the community.Metaculus: a prediction website with an eye on science and technology, in YaleNews published November 2, 2016 retrieved March 16, 2019 Users can earn points for successful predictions (or lose points for unsuccessful predictions), and track their own predictive progress.Forecasting the Future: Can The Hive Mind Let Us Predict the Future?, in Futurism, published September 16th 2016, retrieved March 16, 2019 The scoring awards points both for being right and for being more right than the community.Metaculus FAQ In January 2020, Metaculus introduced the Bentham Prize, which awards bi-weekly monetary prizes of $300, $200 and $100 to the first, second and third most valuable user contributions. The following month, Metaculus introduced the Li Wenliang prize, which awards a number of different monetary prizes to questions, forecasts and analyses related to the COVID-19 outbreak. ==History== Data scientist Max Wainwright and physicists Greg Laughlin and Anthony Aguirre launched the site in 2015.Metaculus: a prediction website with an eye on science and technology, in YaleNews published November 2, 2016 retrieved March 16, 2019The power of prediction markets, in Nature, published 18 October 2016 retrieved March 16, 2019 In June 2017, the Metaculus prediction was launched, which is a system for aggregating user's predictions.Metaculus Track Record' The Metaculus prediction, on average, outperforms the median of the community's predictions when evaluated using the Brier or Log scoring rules.Forecasting the Future: Can The Hive Mind Let Us Predict the Future?, in Futurism, published September 16th 2016, retrieved March 16, 2019 ==References== == External links == *Metaculus website Category:Prediction
